I love basketball and I find writing about it even more thrilling. I learn new things about the sport and equipment every day that I would never know about without starting this website.', 'I hope you find the information on this site valuable if not please send me an email with a few tips or changes you want me to change in order to make it more helpful.', 'About Morris', 'Morriss strong passion for sports was clearly seen by his parents when he was just 11 years old. Since then his love for sports kept increasing since then and his focus moved towards physical sports which later on ended with the love for basketball.', 'Our Reviews and Blogs', 'Recently we have reviewed some of the basketball accessories like\xa0Best Kids Basketball Hoops\xa0Best Basketball Hoops and\xa0Best Outdoor Basketball Shoes. title: 5 notes on how to succeed with AI
subtitle: None
tags: ['Open in app', 'Meninger', 'Trender', 'Produkter', 'Folk', 'Prosess', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Digital Transformation', 'Digitalization', 'Machine Learning', 'Business Strategy']
author: Elin Hauge
h2_headers: ['Dont waste your time on Proof of Concept  it only ends up in a drawer somewhere anyway.', '1. Its not about technology its about the business value you want to achieve', '2. Get out of Proof of Concept hell!', '3. Your most important asset is STILL your employees', '4. Making the decision to invest in AI is great! But remember that THATs when the hard work begins…', '5. The speed of change is increasing exponentially']
paragraphs: ['Ive been around in the consulting industry since 2014. Before that I was a very critical buyer of consulting services which I believe has made me a better advisor and sparring partner for my current customers. In these glorious and adventurous days of artificial intelligence this critical sense has proved particularly important. The market is so full of magic dust and unrealistic promises about what artificial intelligence may bring in terms of prosperity success and eternal customer satisfaction. Working in this landscape every day with some of the most brilliant data scientists I have ever met Im also convinced that the world as we know it is changing and artificial intelligence plays an essential role. When I listen to lectures read articles and books or just reflect on the teams work I make notes in my very analogue black Moleskine which is always tagging along in my mobile handbag office. Here are five of my most important notes:', 'Ive been in many a customer meeting where the customer wants to assess different technologies for AI. Seriously it doesnt matter. Artificial intelligence is about applying mathematics and statistics to data usually solved through the programming language Python. Its like spending hours on debating the brand of screwdrivers with your carpenter. Dont. They will choose whatever works best for their purpose given the context of the job at hand. What matters to them and even more to you is what you want your house to look like when the work is done. If you fail in expressing what you want to achieve you are very likely to be extremely unsatisfied and youll have to redo the work.', 'The terms Proof of Concept (PoC) and pilot are often used interchangeably. They do mean different things though and the outputs are potentially VERY different. A PoC is about testing a concept or a technology to verify whether it makes sense in a given context. Typically a PoC is executed on very limited prerequisites with limited data and low precision requirements and without interaction with the surrounding operational environment. Consequently the results of the proof of concept typically ends up in a drawer far away from the CFOs nose. A pilot on the other hand is a limited production scope which means you start small but still aim for a full production scope and you have to think through the operational implications from the very start. It also means that youll be encouraged to prioritize processes that are truly relevant for your core business.', 'Lets have an example: A utilities company wants to develop a machine learning model to predict downtime of windmills in order to schedule maintenance with a proactive and preventive approach. The technical manager is an experienced guy with a long track-record in maintaining heavy equipment. No matter how good the predictive maintenance model you develop is you still need to convince the technical maintenance manager that his experience and gut feeling is about to be replaced (or better complemented) by an algorithm. If he is not in on this from the beginning dont waste your money (or your time) because in his eyes the algorithm will fail no matter how useful it couldve been. Yes artificial intelligence is about algorithms but your business is ultimately about people (your employees) who again work with people (customers).', 'Ive seen this scare some leaders into decision paralysis. Dont worry just start small and always keep your eyes on your business targets. Artificial intelligence is not magic. Its hard work experience and science. All those data you have collected for years are lying around waiting to be utilized. Structured systematic work by resources that are specialists in understanding the science of data in combination with your best domain specialists. Together they will unveil new insight about your business processes. Potentially worth millions. Perhaps hundreds of millions. Ive seen it happen.', 'Do you still believe that you can spend six months on strategy revisions? And another six months concluding on the business case? Sorry those days are over and theyre not likely to come back any time soon. You still need your long-term foundation and on top of that you need to develop an agile top management approach continuously learning from customers sparring partners and expert resources in the market. The days when a company could build and nurture all required competence and capacity internally are officially over.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']
bold_text: ['1.', 'Its not about technology its about the business value you want to achieve', '2.', 'Get out of Proof of Concept hell!', '3.', 'Your most important asset is STILL your employees', '4.', 'Making the decision to invest in AI is great! But remember that THATs when the hard work begins…', '5.', 'The speed of change is increasing exponentially']

title: AI: Hype or headache?
subtitle: None
author: Elin Hauge
h2_headers: ['Dont let the dystopian image of AI scare you away from understanding how it actually affects your business.']
paragraphs: ['According to the pundits artificial intelligence (AI) can lead to a utopian future or overtake and destroy society. While there are proven use cases of AI and increasing investments in pragmatic applications this is outweighed by the hype factor  all the while we continue signing up for many more conferences summits and webinars on the topic.', 'Today still only 4% of European companies are using AI for several processes in the same business and in advanced tasks according to a report commissioned by Microsoft and conducted by EY [1]. 61% have started planning or are in the pilot phase of their first initiative. In a study by Siemens [2] 68% of the business leaders asked expect digitalization in general to primarily increase the efficiency of work processes while only 32% believe that digitalization will bring new business opportunities or new business models. At the same time the death of traditional retailers has become an international plague. How come? Why are companies moving so slowly when it comes to embracing digitalization in general and AI in particular? What will it take to speed up this progress?', 'Ill throw three hypotheses on the table:', 'What can we do then to speed up the rate of digitalization and application of AI?', 'My take is as follows: If you want to be part of the future of business as a leader or board member there is no way around it you have to upgrade your digital competence. You cannot just assign everything digital to some chief digital officer and continue with your own business as usual. There are many ways of achieving that necessary level of competence such as reading books and articles listening to podcasts watching Youtube inviting digital experts for a coffee signing up for a course etc. Whatever. Just do it. After all the key to succeeding with AI is NOT about technology its about our understanding of the technology.', '[1] Artificial Intelligence in Europe. Norway  Outlook for 2019 and Beyond report commissioned by Microsoft and conducted by EY', '[2] Digital temperaturmåler for norsk næringsliv 2019 report conducted by Siemens', '[3] P. Weill T. Apel L. Woerner J.S. Banner Assessing the Impact of a Digitally Savvy Board on Company Performance MIT Sloan CISR Working Paper №433 January 2019', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']
italic_text: ['Assessing the Impact of a Digitally Savvy Board on Company Performance', 'Følg 3min på Facebook', 'så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

title: Digging for value in the text mines
subtitle: None
tags: ['Open in app', 'Meninger', 'Trender', 'Produkter', 'Folk', 'Prosess', 'Machine Learning', 'Data Science', 'Enterprise Technology', 'Oil And Gas', 'Digitalization']
author: Jesse Lord
h2_headers: ['The oil and gas industrys new toolset is transforming document swamps and making data more accessible.', 'Text is a four-letter word']
paragraphs: ['Our success at Amazon is a function of how many experiments we do per year per month per week per day.  Jeff Bezos', 'Since the advent of the internet many of our digitalisation projects have achieved little more than transforming a physical collection of books on a shelf to a collection of documents in a directory. Even today much of the information used to make key decisions in any industry resides in reports articles books and electronic communiqué. Natural Language Processing is a collection of techniques used to extract actionable information from these unstructured collections. It is being used today for a variety of tasks from finance (to extract signals from news articles as input to trading algorithms) to search engine queries and machine translation.', 'A tremendous amount of resources are devoted to machine learning activities within the Exploration & Production departments of the worlds Oil & Gas companies. Progress is being made on automating key workflows and some scientific literature can even be processed efficiently enough to perform sentiment analysis. But while we spend a great deal of time discussing our metrics and methodologies data scientists still spend an inordinate amount of time on preparing the data.', 'The Norwegian National Data Repository for exploration and production data (Diskos) contains over 26 000 publicly available reports. We can quickly scan and index the content of these documents to make them easy to search but programmatically extracting further meaning is not a trivial matter. When I consider the amount of time and money that has gone into the creation of each of these reports it seems a great pity that the only reliable way to derive full value from them is for a seasoned expert with a good memory to read them and disseminate the knowledge throughout their organisation.', 'To pick just one example of the kind of value that can be extracted from a text document; consider the references to good shows found in final well reports. Last year I was lucky enough to be part of a team at the Force Machine Learning Hackathon where we programmatically extracted these good shows with depth from Final Well Reports and plotted them on an interactive map. Check out the write-up here.', 'While there is no quick fix for extracting value from unstructured text files Id like to recommend a simple step towards the structured utopia so often featured on those glossy PowerPoint slides. Enter insight engines.', 'An insight engine is conceptually similar to a data lake: it automatically crawls through the various data sources in an enterprise (internal and external) and allows users to quickly answer a complex query typically via a web interface. If you want to find a set of documents containing a specific word or phrase for example both solutions allow you to rapidly locate them based on content or associated metadata. The difference lies in the connectors enrichment and natural language search capabilities.', 'Consider what is required for the insight engine to answer a question such as: Which log files do I have for wellbores that have a bottom depth in the Tarbert formation?', 'This query relies on data sources enriched metadata and natural language specific to the oil & gas industry and would only be relevant for companies operating in the Norwegian Continental Shelf. To honour this request the insight engine needs to understand all the different potential formats of log file (both the open standards and those that reside within E&P projects/databases) what a wellbore entity is what its bottom depth is and finally reconcile this bottom depth with the lithostratigraphic formation data (which could come from a variety of sources). Finally once the structured elements hidden within the question have been assembled relevant records from a variety of different sources are presented to the user. Because of this complexity many insight engine vendors focus on a single vertical. My company (KADME) is no exception and we focus exclusively on the E&P vertical with our insight engine Whereoil.', 'This kind of enrichment can be very useful as a basis for building machine learning models that take advantage of natural language processing. We can get a number of features for free without needing to engineer them manually. Further by building our query to pull data from an API we can integrate live data into the pipeline. This keeps our models alive and relevant and gives us the option of phasing out older data that may no longer be helpful. If you have access to a platform like this in your organisation consider integrating its API into your machine learning pipeline.', 'Data wrangling may not be particularly exciting but it is very time consuming. Using an insight engine that understands your industry and comes with a robust open API can really streamline the process. This means more time to iterate optimise and ultimately get more experiments done using the same project resources.']
blockquotes: ['“Our success at Amazon is a function of how many experiments we do per year, per month, per week, per day.” — Jeff Bezos']

title: Gjør roboter smartere med enkle grep
subtitle: None
author: Oda Aase Johnsen
h2_headers: ['En automatisert prosess kan spare deg både penger og tid men hvorfor ikke sikre deg den beste du kan?']
paragraphs: ['Antall ledere som mener de trenger et «RPA-prosjekt» for å få automatisert prosessene sine øker stadig. Det mange ikke er klar over er at RPA (Robotic Process Automation) alene ofte ikke er den beste løsningen de kunne ha fått.', 'Når en bruker RPA for å automatisere prosesser slipper man å tenke på integrasjon mellom IT-systemene som berøres av en prosess fordi RPA forholder seg direkte til brukergrensesnittet. Kort forklart arbeider en RPA-robot som en vanlig ansatt med i all hovedsak de samme klikkene som en fysisk medarbeider og kan åpne og lukke programmer etter behov. Dette er en stor lettelse for ledere som i mange år har måttet skrinlegge IT-prosjekter grunnet tid og kostnader. Bruker en RPA kan en relativt kompleks prosess bli ferdig automatisert på få uker. At mange ledere derfor kontakter ulike leverandører av rene RPA-løsninger er dermed ganske lett å forstå.', 'Det mange ledere derimot ikke er klar over er at det er mulig å kombinere RPA med for eksempel API-spørringer (Application Programming Interface). API-er kan sammenlignes med en servitør på en restaurant. Du forteller servitøren hva du ønsker å spise servitøren formidler dette videre til kokken som lager maten og til slutt kommer servitøren tilbake med maten du har bestilt. Ved hjelp av API-spørringer kan du for eksempel «snakke med» CRM-systemet ditt uten å skulle arbeide direkte på brukergrensesnittet. Dette er ofte en langt mer robust løsning fordi en da ikke må «lære opp roboten» på nytt dersom det blir endringer på brukergrensesnittet. I eksempelet med servitøren betyr dette for eksempel at du ikke trenger å skulle tenke på om kjøkkenverktøyet plutselig ligger på en annen plass enn tidligere.', 'Videre kan en også kombinere RPA med blant annet språkmotorer som kan tolke ustrukturert tekst. Nyttiggjør en seg av dette kan roboten din dermed ikke bare arbeide basert på forhåndsdefinerte regler men den har faktisk blitt en god del smartere.', 'For å ende opp med den beste løsningen er det med andre ord viktig å endre tankegangen fra at virksomheten trenger et «RPA-prosjekt» til at virksomheten trenger å få automatisert en prosess på best mulig måte uavhengig av teknologi.']

title: Kan du digitalisere en gjennomdigitalisert bransje?
subtitle: None
tags: ['Open in app', 'Meninger', 'Trender', 'Produkter', 'Folk', 'Prosess', 'Digital Transformation', 'Oil And Gas', 'Machine Learning', 'Digitalization', 'Exploration']
author: Vidar Furuholt
h2_headers: ['Her er tre tips for å hente ut store digitaliseringsgevinster også i Norges mest høyteknologiske industri.']
paragraphs: ['Leting etter olje og gass er en industri som i mange tiår har skjøvet grenser for digital teknologi. Seismiske undersøkelser genererer enorme mengder data og til prosessering og analyse av disse benyttes noen av de største regneklyngene som til enhver tid er å oppdrive. Avansert modellering og simulering 3D-visualisering og automatisert geologisk tolkning har vært en del av letegeologenes- og geofysikernes verktøykasse i en årrekke. Oljedirektoratets database for seismikk og brønndata på norsk sokkel Diskos inneholder omlag 10 petabyte data og vokser raskt.', 'Hva betyr begrepet digitalisering for en bransje og et fagområde som har vært blant de ledende på bruk av digital teknologi siden hullkortenes tid?', 'Det første er erkjennelsen av at data kun kan oppnå full nytteverdi når de er enkelt tilgjengelige for bruk. En historikk for datainnsamling som strekker seg over et halvt århundre og en like lang arv av programvare for håndtering av disse har gitt et mylder av filformater databaser og lagringssystemer med dårlig innbyrdes kompatibilitet. Resultatet er at data vanskelig lar seg hente ut av ett system for å benyttes i et annet og data fra ulike fagdisipliner er tungvinte å sammenstille for analyse på tvers. I tillegg er dataene ofte dårlig strukturert og har mangelfull metainformasjon noe som gjør det vanskelig å se sammenheng mellom objekter og vurdere datakvalitet. Det jobbes derfor intensivt hos en rekke aktører i bransjen med å etablere dataplattformer som kan frigjøre data fra deres opprinnelige formater og lagringssystemer øke kontekstualiseringen og bedre tilgjengeligheten for applikasjoner. Sentrale elementer her er utvikling av robuste datamodeller og APIer for datautveksling samt standardisering av disse. Hvilken mekanisme som skal sørge for standardisering er ennå et åpent spørsmål  både konsortier kommersielle grupperinger og myndighetsinitiativ kan vise seg å definere retningen. Trolig er det den som greier å etablere nok moment til å få nettverkseffekten på sin side som stikker av med seieren. Det viktigste er uansett at bransjen evner å lande på teknisk gode standarder med størst mulig grad av åpenhet og fleksibilitet for tilpasning til spesifikke behov.', 'Videre er maskinlæring et sentralt begrep i digitalisering også for letebransjen. Maskinlæring generelt har lange tradisjoner innenfor geofagene  autotolkning av seismikk har eksempelvis eksistert i mange år  men store nevrale nettverk er relativt nytt. Prestasjonen til store nevrale nettverk bestemmes først og fremst av mengde og kvalitet av treningsdata. Det betyr at desto mer aktørene i bransjen åpner opp og deler sine data desto bedre kan verktøy basert på nevrale nettverk bli  for alle. Deling av data krever to elementer: tekniske løsninger som gode dataplattformer med åpne APIer og motivasjon til å dele hos de som eier data. På norsk sokkel har vi gode rammeverk for deling og offentliggjøring av data sammenlignet med mange andre land gjennom stabile myndighetsbestemmelser og tekniske løsninger som nevnte Diskos. Likevel er store mengder data proprietære og dermed utilgjengelige for allmenheten. Bransjen utfordres nå til å vurdere etablerte forretningsmodeller rundt eierskap til data i lys av det nye verdipotensialet som ligger i større grad av datadeling for maskinlæring.', 'Med god datatilgang i bunn er neste steg å finne fram til de verdifulle anvendelsene for maskinlæring og nevrale nettverk. Oljeindustrien støtter både offentlig og privat forskning og utvikling med betydelige midler innenfor dette området og interessen er raskt økende i takt med at spennende løsninger utvikles og kommer ut i markedet. Et hackathon sist høst sponset av en rekke oljeselskaper leverandører og Oljedirektoratet genererte prosjekter på blant annet mønstergjenkjenning på seismikk automatisk analyse av kjerneprøver fra brønner og et verktøy til å omsette håndskisser til syntetiske data. Men her har vi ennå bare skrapt i overflaten av mulighetsrommet. Bedre allmenn tilgang til relevante letedata vil kunne løfte økosystemet av utviklere og leverandører og betydelig øke tilfanget av gode ideer.', 'Begrepet digitalisering er i ferd med å konkretiseres for letebransjen og aktørene begynner å få øynene opp for mulighetene og verdipotensialet. Men for å lykkes er det ikke nok at aktørene investerer i egne prosjekter. Man må også evne å samarbeide både med partnere og konkurrenter være villig til å dele kunnskap og teknologi og til og med vurdere egen forretningsmodell og rolle i markedet. Det er utfordrende men gevinsten ved å lykkes er større enn ulempene.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']
italic_text: ['Følg 3min på Facebook', 'så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

title: Let’s Look at Oslo City Bike Data
subtitle: None
author: Dmitry Semashkov
h2_headers: ['With more than 50000 members and 2.7 million rides made in 2017 Oslo City Bike has long been an important part of the local transport system.']
paragraphs: ['The company that runs the service regularly releases historic trip data. That gives us an opportunity to explore and visualize bike rides and quite possibly get an insight into some patterns of usage.', 'The animation below displays all of the bicycle trips that occurred on a specific day 15 September 2017. Since the data only contains the station where each journey started and the station where it finished I created an estimated path which follows the cycling directions from Google Maps from start to finish.', 'It is possible to notice some regular patterns. First we can notice two busy periods  in the morning from 8:00 to 9:00 and in the evening from 15:00 to 19:00. The rest of the day is less busy.', 'We can find this trend in the data if we plot the number of bike rides by hour of the day. It makes sense to look at the data for weekdays separately since the behavior is quite different during weekends.', 'Another trend is a little bit more subtle and relates to the direction of travel. Lets have a look at the number of bike journeys started at specific stations throughout the day:', 'In the morning we can see how areas outside of city center light up. Then in the evening the same happens in the central areas. Clearly there are more bikes used outside of city center in the morning and in the center in the evening. But we have seen where the journey starts. Lets have a look where it ends.', 'But before we check the data lets have one more look at our original animation. We can paint the bikes going in and out of the city center with different colors:', 'We can clearly see more green dots during the morning peak (meaning more trips to the center) and more purple dots during the evening peak (out of center). Lets verify this by checking the data:', 'Again we found evidence. Interesting that a lot of people seem to travel both in and out of city during evening peak. I speculate that while some people use city bikes to commute to/from work other people are attracted to the city center and all the services it offers  be it restaurants shopping etc. but thats just a guess.', 'Lets have look at other usage statistics to get an idea about how the Oslo City Bike operates.', 'If we look at the number of trips made in 2017 we can clearly see seasonal variations:', 'At the same time there is not much variation in the number of trips taken on a day to day basis except for weekends when people seem to take the city bike less often…', '…but for longer periods:', 'Also I was quite surprised to find out that short trips are much more common than long trips. Trips lasting 4 10 minutes happen much more often than any other trips:', 'Probably unsurprising is the distribution between the most used and the least used stations  it seems that stations closer to center are used most. Usage during one day:', 'It seems that the pattern does not change much if we zoom out and collect statistics for the whole month:', 'This last map is the heatmap which approximates the roads most frequently used by cyclists in September 2017. As before the precise route is not known so every rider is assumed to use Google Maps to navigate from pickup station to the return station).', 'Yet again the statistics collected for the whole month only differ from the daily statistics in minor details which can be easily observed if you follow the links and compare the maps.', 'Its quite interesting to see how things are changing with time. If you look at the excellent analysis of 2016 bike data made by Jon Olav H. Eikenes you can see that while some patterns didnt change there is a tendency for shorter bike trips in 2017 compared to 2016.', 'There is always room for further analysis: correlation to weather and air quality traffic conditions predicting the journeys on station levels analyzing the need for new stations comparing bike systems to public transport data or taxi etc. etc. etc.  just a short list of topics this study could be extended to. Maybe next time!']

title: Maskinlæring for mennesker
subtitle: None
author: Knut Melvær
h2_headers: ['Også når det gjelder teknologi er det slik at om noe er for fantastisk til å være sant så er det gjerne det: ikke sant.', 'Påfuglens vifting', 'Turgåer i data-landskap', 'En del av hverdagen', 'Menneskelig kreativitet']
paragraphs: ['Robotene kommer! Arbeidsplassen din vil bli automatisert. Om et par år er det ingen som kjører selv lengre. Kampen om algoritmene vil føre til tredje verdenskrig. Datamaskiner vil oppdage sykdommer lenge før fastlegen din. Inn fra venstre kommer det språkteknologi som vil snu opp ned på språkforskningen. Menneskeheten er i ferd med å skape en intelligens større enn seg selv. Med de siste utviklingene innenfor kunstig intelligens står vi nå i et uavklart sted mellom utopi og dystopi. Vil utviklingen føre til vår undergang eller vår frelse?', 'Det er i hvert fall ikke rart at det snakkes mye om maskinlæring og kunstig intelligens i mediene for tiden. De som følger med i dingseverdenen har trolig også fått med seg et at teknologigigantene ikke nøler med å bruke dette i markedsføringen av sine produkter. Det å hevde at man mestrer og kan bruke maskinlæring er nå markedets svar på påfuglens vifting med en alt for stor halestjert. Til tross for at teknologien maskinvaren og datastrømmene aldri har vært mer tilgjengelige så er maskinlæring vanskelig i praksis. Hovedsakelig fordi man trenger menneskelig hjernekraft for å lære maskinene til å lære som mennesker. Men investorene flokker seg rundt allikevel  og man kan spørre seg om troen fremdeles er mer drivende i markedet enn fornuften.', 'Grunnen er nok at det er få som tar seg bryet med å forklare hva maskinlæring egentlig er for noe. Jeg prøvde meg på det tidligere i vår i to seminarer jeg holdt for studenter i Digital kultur ved Det humanistiske Fakultet på UiB. Ideene bak maskinlæring  som tross alt også er et bredt felt  er ganske overkommelige om man tar vekk den tekniske sjargongen.', 'Det ble også klart for oss hvor lett det er å ta maskinlæringens frukter for gitt og hvor viktig det er at vi også lærer oss å tenke kritisk på områder hvor det er lett å la seg rive med.', 'På post-it lappene vi brukte i undervisningen hadde studentene skrevet ord som «intuisjon» «objektivitet» «følelser» «etikk» «juss» og «singulariteten». Bak matematikken som kraftige maskiner bruker på masse data ligger det vanskelige spørsmål som har vært med menneskeheten fra vi selv fikk tankekraft nok til å tenke i bilder og symboler.', 'Men grunnprinsippene er likevel enkle: Målet er å finne en slags oppskrift som kan brukes for å kategorisere noe fra noe annet  helst uten at vi trenger å fortelle dataprogrammet så mye om hvordan den skal gjøre det selv. Det er en del forskjellige innfallsvinkler til hvordan vi gjør dette i praksis men de innebærer stort sett at datamaskiner regner seg frem til veldig mange sannsynligheter mellom veldig mange variabler på veldig mye data for å så trekke dette sammen i en modell som vi kan bruke videre.', 'Vi kan tenke oss dataprogrammet som en turgåer i et stort kupert data-landskap som forandrer seg litt hele tiden. Turgåeren går ned over dalen litt på måfå og prøver å ikke sette seg fast i busker eller søkk. Vi kan be vandreren å ta med seg noen erfaringer fra tidligere turer eller konkurrere med en annen turgåer. Vi kan også plassere noen varder i landskapet som hjelper turgåeren litt på vei.', 'Det som gjør maskinlæring rart er at vi sliter med å forklare hvordan turgåeren har tenkt på veien og hvorfor hen alltid kommer frem til den avtalte møteplassen. Vi vet at det antageligvis er noe mer enn flaks.', 'Hver uke blir det publisert nye akademiske artikler fra de som jobber med dette hos teknologigigantene hvor man har gjort nye oppdagelser men samtidig påpeker hvor dårlig det er forstått.', 'Denne uvissheten gir også feltet en mystisk aura. Løftet om kunstig intelligens  som i dag tillegges maskinlæring  ligger tett opp til ideer vi har utforsket i science fiction og populærkulturen siden før den kunstige intelligensen HAL9000 i Stanley Kubrick og Arthur C. Clarkes 2001 A Space Odyssey. Slik kunstig intelligens blir ofte fremstilt som allvitende gudelignende vesen med intensjoner og hensikter utenfor vår kontroll. Det er fristende å bruke det latinske religionsvitenskapelige uttrykket «mysterium tremendum et fascinans»; opplevelsen av noe vi ikke helt forstår og finner både attraktivt og skummelt.', 'Og samtidig er maskinlæring en del av hverdagen vår. Vi har allerede hatt maskinlærings-boter som har handlet på aksjemarkedet i over ti år og det er få som hever et øyebryn når bildesøket til Google fungerer som forventet. De skeptiske øyenbrynene bør senke seg når det hevdes at man besitter maskinlærings-teknologi som skal løse brede og generelle problemområder som for eksempel diagnostisering personalhåndtering eller husarbeid.', 'Også når det gjelder teknologi er det slik at om noe er for fantastisk til å være sant så er det gjerne det: ikke sant. Maskinlæring står kun for en liten del av det som får «smarte» løsninger til å fungere. Man må også inn med god gammaldags programmering design og kostnadseffektive prioriteringer. Det trengs med andre ord fremdeles en solid porsjon menneskelig kreativitet pågangsmot og utholdenhet for å skape morgendagens løsninger. Da holder det ikke kun med markedsføring.', 'Denne teksten er også publisert på Sysla.no']
bold_text: ['Også når det gjelder teknologi er det slik at om noe er for fantastisk til å være sant så er det gjerne det: ikke sant.']
italic_text: ['2001 A Space Odyssey', 'mysterium tremendum et fascinans', '»', 'Denne teksten er også publisert på Sysla.n', 'o']

title: Should you bother developing a recommendation engine?
subtitle: None
author: Didrik Finnoy
h2_headers: ['Its all about providing the users with buttons they want to push and theres plenty of room to be creative.', 'Heres a bunch of stuff wed like you to consume', 'Here are a bunch of suggestions you might actually find helpful', 'Size matters', 'An unusual example', 'So should you bother developing a recommendation engine?']
paragraphs: ['We need to talk about recommendation engines. Over the past decade theres been a tremendous push toward data-driven marketing and personalized customer experiences; a recent survey by Harris Poll indicates that most people expect consumer experiences to be tailored toward their individual tastes and preferences. At first glance a recommendation engine may seem like an elegant way for online retailers to fulfill this somewhat vague expectation. Before pursuing this type of technology one should think carefully about how it will benefit customers  it might not be the type of personalization theyre asking for.', 'The principal idea behind a recommender system is to present consumers with products and services they might be interested in with respect to what the system knows about them. Most of the time the business value of these systems is to boost sales. In that sense one could argue that personalized content is just a fancy word for effective advertising. Have you ever caught yourself thinking Gosh life sure would be sweeter if that screen space contained more relevant advertisements? I would wager that your answer is no. After decades of enduring that colorful noise often decorated with scantily clad supermodels weve grown accustomed to ignoring the automated salesman. In most cases nobody would notice the absence of an excellent recommendation engine.', 'Its important to remember that contexts differ and that personalized recommendations can be very useful. Imagine if YouTube suddenly abandoned their recommender systems in favor of simply listing content in alphabetical order. People would be outraged… or at least mildly inconvenienced. There are certain websites on the internet where recommendation engines play a crucial role in how consumers interact with content  YouTube and Netflix being prominent examples. For sites like Amazon this is arguably less true. Sure there are Amazon shoppers who enjoy browsing their personal recommendations but I think the average customer wouldnt care if Amazon replaced their recommender systems with completely random product suggestions. E-commerce websites differ in the extent that consumers actually benefit from recommendation engines. For most Amazon customers a product handpicked by the engine is just another advertisement while on YouTube the same type of system can be instrumental in deciding whether one ends up bored or entertained. The distinction between pushing content to boost revenue and actually helping customers can be difficult to pinpoint. Most of the time a recommender system ends up doing both.', 'When I read about developing recommendation engines (I work as a Data Science Consultant at Atea so Im sometimes asked to build such systems) I frequently come across the following piece of advice:', 'Dont build a recommendation engine unless your website gets a lot of traffic.', 'The rationale behind the advice is perfectly reasonable: If you dont get a lot of traffic from shoppers visiting your website your recommendation engine wont get many opportunities to create value. I dont necessarily think that this is good advice. Sure it makes sense if your goal is to turn a profit but thats not the only motivation one might have to develop a recommender system. For sites like Netflix recommendation engines are all about the user experience. The engines are valuable irrespective of how many people subscribe to their service. Traffic is still relevant because it determines how much time and resources it makes sense to invest in improving the system. Back when Netflix only had a few thousand customers a simple solution would probably be better than nothing but it wouldnt make sense to spend big money without expecting something in return. Today Netflixs recommender systems probably have a big impact on churn prevention and maintaining a competitive edge and Im sure the sizable investments theyve made toward developing their recommendation technology are paying off. From Amazons point of view their size is what makes recommender systems worth the effort even if the average shopper tends to completely ignore their recommendations. When you have hundreds of millions of customers the occasional extra sale generated through recommendations can amount to sizable figures.', 'Ive been assisting a local brewery Hansa Borg Bryggerier with developing a recommendation engine for their online sales portal. A prerequisite for accessing this portal is that you must hold a license to serve alcohol in Norway. This means that relatively few businesses are allowed to use the website and that its never going to see large amounts of traffic. If we were to follow the advice referenced above we wouldve abandoned the idea of developing a recommender system. We didnt abandon it because Hansa Borg saw great potential with respect to personalizing the customer experience.', 'The goal behind this particular system was to assist customers in the hospitality sector when they perform the regular task of ordering beverages and supplies. Using a recommender system to boost sales probably wouldnt work well in this context. Bars and restaurants are a lot less likely to make frivolous purchases compared to individuals shopping for miscellaneous products on Amazon. Taking on a new product usually entails extra work (updating menus training staff etc.) which isnt what bar and restaurant managers have on their mind when they contact Hansa Borg to restock their supplies.', 'Every recommendation engine needs some sort of key performance indicators. For Amazon this is probably clicks or purchases or both. For Hansa Borg the KPIs were how long it takes a customer to get the job done and how often they have to come back to order more stuff within the same week. Its not uncommon for their customers to place several orders within a single week usually because they forget some stuff the first time around. Our ambition was to minimize the time spent on the site and help customers find everything they need on the first attempt. These business goals presented us with the need for a somewhat unusual recommendation engine.', 'Under the hood the goal of most recommender systems is to find products similar to the stuff youve consumed in the past. The traditional recommender algorithms would not do the trick for us instead we defined our task as a time-series classification problem. This is a fairly established type of problem in the world of machine learning but I have not seen it employed within the context of product recommendations before which is why I have the audacity to claim that our recommendation engine is an unusual one.', 'Hansa Borg has a fairly good idea about what each customer is going to order in the future because their menus are quite stable over time. The main source of uncertainty is when they will need to resupply the various items on the menu. As it turns out this is a question that machine learning algorithms are well equipped to answer. After feeding historical sales data through several candidate classification algorithms we began seeing promising results fairly early in the process. The vision of a website where the first thing you see is exactly what you need was firmly within reach. As a matter of fact this feature is about to go live and Im fairly excited about it. The Hansa brand is part of the cultural identity of my home town; this is the beer my grandfather drank and Im known for consuming responsible quantities of it myself. It has been a real honor and a privilege to make my own small contribution toward their wider goal of becoming a more data-driven organization.', 'Whether or not recommender systems make sense for your website depends entirely on your context. If youre certain that it will benefit your customers I would say go for it  but be mindful of the costs. If its all about boosting sales and unlikely to actually benefit your customers then the size will be pivotal; dont bother unless youre seeing a lot of traffic. Like most things in business costs should be weighed against benefits. These days you can develop a recommender system in less than a day it doesnt have to be fancy and there are plenty of off-the-shelf solutions that will probably do the trick just fine.', 'In my opinion famous examples like Netflix and Amazon are dominating the literature on recommender systems. Most tutorials blog posts and how-to guides are geared toward tackling the problem in terms of collaborative- or content-based filtering forgetting that the concept of providing personalized recommendations is much broader. Dont abandon the idea of developing a recommender system simply because the Netflix / Amazon approach doesnt fit your context. When we break it down to the core concept its all about providing users with buttons that they want to push; there is plenty of room to be creative. Whatever your ambitions are with respect to technology make sure you think big start small and move fast.', 'Dette innlegget ble originalt publisert hos Atea og her kan du lese mer om deres arbeid med Hansa Borg Bryggeri.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']
blockquotes: ['Don’t build a recommendation engine unless your website gets a lot of traffic.']
bold_text: ['most people expect consumer experiences to be tailored toward their individual tastes and preferences']
